Speaker: arlyn
Dialogue: Cappy? --

Speaker: arlyn
Dialogue: Oh baby -- no it's all right -- oh my baby baby baby --

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: She wouldn't be reliable anyhow -- a narcotics addict.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I believed her, Pete.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: He's right you know. Waiting for the pusher, she'd tell you anything.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I believed her: the Dumper was not Tom Grunemann.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: All right, suppose it wasn't Tom Grunemann; where does that get you?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: It's where it doesn't get me. I've got nothing left that connects to anything.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: Then, close the case.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I better keep looking.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: Where, how?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I could try Arlyn Page again. She saw much more of the Dumper than Bree Daniel.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: You just finished telling me she had nothing to offer. Not Tom, you said, the Dumper was clearly not Tom.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: It's got to make sense some way.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: Mr. Cable -- they are meeting in Mr. Camara's office.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: Yes Evvie, thanks. Gentlemen, I'm sorry.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: How is it back there?

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: I think you're homesick.  John, I'll be back here again Thursday; I'll be in touch. Lieutenant, thank you.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: They were bringing a freighter down through Kill Van Kull; propellers washed it up on top.

Speaker: sugarman
Dialogue: Why didn't you bring it up on deck?

Speaker: deckhand
Dialogue: Would you bring it up on deck?

Speaker: spence
Dialogue: They'll drop off theirselves when she comes out.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: It'll go to the Examiner. But I don't see nothin that means nothin.

Speaker: sugarman
Dialogue: You help us with ID? We can't get nothin from him.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Arlyn Page was probably an alias. She went by the names Terry Arlyn and June Price. She may have been from Pittsburgh, someone told me. I can give you a list of people who knew her, if that would help to --

Speaker: sugarman
Dialogue: No point, thanks.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Is he claiming the body?

Speaker: sugarman
Dialogue: Uh uh, that'd mean funeral expenses.

Speaker: berger
Dialogue: Man could you help me?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Yeah, what?

Speaker: berger
Dialogue: You know, help me out. That's my baby there, dead. I got to get up.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: -- You've got to get up.

Speaker: berger
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: That's how the other one died, you know. In the water.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I looked it up.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Well hello -- come on in.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I thought you ought to know, Arlyn Page is dead.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: The same as Jane McKenna.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Thanks for the jolly news. I thought maybe you'd left town by now. You kind of just disappeared. But you boys from Tuscarora have a habit of disappearing, don't you?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: The next few weeks I would like to know where you are all the time.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Just let me know when you are going out and where --

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: What if i go out on tricks - you wanna come along? You could sit and read the National Geographic.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: How can you do it to yourself?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: I don't get you.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Ligourin: How could you do it?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: I told you before, you wouldn't understand.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: You're right, I don't understand. Explain it to me.  You were scared. Arlyn Page, that scared you. Well it should; that's death. So what did you do, you ran straight for it, death. Ligourin kills women.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: No, no you're right, I'm sorry. He uses women; he lets them kill themselves. Is that how you want it?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Arlyn was a junkie; I'm not on junk!

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: No, you can find some other way.  Explain it to me. Bree, show me any sense to --

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: You get the Christ out! You dumb stupid bastard, you don't know anything, you square, you get out! I don't have to show you anything; you get out!

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: If I asked you something, would you not laugh? -- asked you to look at something?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: It's been a full day.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: We did this before.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: No.  Well all right. But you want to and I want you to and we both know it and all right.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I don't like getting splashed.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: OK ----- OK

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: --- Bree ---

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Go back to sleep.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: I'm still scared.  Look, I made it very clear from the start, you're a yokel, you don't excite me, you don't even interest me, and so I only have one question which is what the hell are you doing in my bed?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: My bed.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Oh!

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Mm.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: No, not just 'mm'. You don't know what I --

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Yup.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Oh --

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: The son of a bitch seduced me!

Speaker: spangler
Dialogue: I'd just be guessing.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Guess!

Speaker: spangler
Dialogue: Maybe this wasn't just a trick. Maybe you're in danger of real love, real involve --

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: I do not love him.

Speaker: spangler
Dialogue: You've spent your life avoiding this. You'll try hard to deny it; you're quite likely to destroy it.

Speaker: custodian
Dialogue: Four -- five -- what number'd I say?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Four ninety-seven, Jane McKenna

Speaker: custodian
Dialogue: -- And I keep the authorization, please.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I thought there'd be more.

Speaker: trask's voice
Dialogue: All right, there's Tom Grunemann, you're right, different margins, different spacing absolutely, sloppy, right.

Speaker: klute's voice
Dialogue: Mm.

Speaker: trask's voice
Dialogue: All right, try this next guy.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: Think this is our guy?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I don't know. It looks familiar to me.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: Thought it might. It's off an arrest report you typed two years ago. Man you wanted samples of everybody.

Speaker: trask's voice
Dialogue: Same margins top and sides. He does best with his middle fingers; you get fainter registration from outside keys like Q, A, L, P and like that. Next thing look around apostrophes, how he hits the space bar before --

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: But what reason could he have? What possible reason?

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: Unless he was involved with Grunemann's disappearance.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I knew Tom never wrote that letter.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: What else do you know?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I never could believe that Tom was a split personality. I never believed he was a Dumper; and I don't believe he disappeared of his own volition; and I don't believe he's alive.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: We have some very tentative circumstantial evidence of freeky behavior, but there's no evidence of murder - there's not even a body.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I don't believe Tom's alive.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Yes, Mr. Cable's office, please.

Speaker: cable's voice
Dialogue: John, how are you?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I'll be sending you on a report tonight.

Speaker: cable's voice
Dialogue: It's a beautiful day in Tuscarora - I don't envy you that humidity in the city.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: It's not so bad.

Speaker: cable's voice
Dialogue: What's in it?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I think Tom Grunemann's dead. I've been a lot of places - I've asked a lot of people. I've found no proof he's around. I've found no proof he was ever around.

Speaker: cable voice
Dialogue: How do you go from that to the idea Tom's dead? Suicide you're suggesting? He killed himself?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: He could've been murdered.

Speaker: cable's voice
Dialogue: I'm sure the FBI and the Police explored that possibility.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: No. They never did, really. But that's what I'm going to recommend. The next step. Unless something --

Speaker: cable's voice
Dialogue: Have you discussed this with them?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: It's in the report.

Speaker: cable's voice
Dialogue: Do they have the report? Have you discussed it with them?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I wanted to give it to you first.

Speaker: cable's voice
Dialogue: All right. All right --  John, just sit tight will you? I'll read your report, I'll discuss it with the others. I'll be back next Thursday, we'll talk the whole thing over then. Nothing til Thursday, all right?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: cable's voice
Dialogue: Thank you. Goodbye, John.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Goodbye, Pete.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: I saw Mr. Faber.  You remember Mr. Faber, don't you?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Is that all you have to say?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: What am I supposed to say?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Well, I told him I wouldn't - uh - go there any more.  I know it's tough to understand, but it wasn't easy. You see, he was nice to me. I mean, it wasn't just him. I got something out of it too I guess. Anyway, I told him I wouldn't go there anymore.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Well, here's your gold star.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Spangler says we have a relationship.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: You and I -- a relationship.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I was wondering what that was.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Hell there's nothing so mysterious about the square life.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Oh Jesus. Oh Jesus.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Don't touch anything.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: You suppose he's a married fella?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: He got in my clothing!

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Drop it.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: My God, I thought it was over. And here I am, daddy, right back at the start.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Bree --

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Right back at the start, right?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Go down in my room.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: You said it was over, right? You said not to worry any more, all over, right?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Go down in my room and wait.

Speaker: ross
Dialogue: But if Cable killed Grunemann why would he get you hired to look for Grunemann?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Because he knew I couldn't leave the case alone. And this way at least he'd keep track of it. And me.

Speaker: ross
Dialogue: What about Grunemann's letters to the girl, everything like that?

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: Cable's letters, Cable's phone calls. Cable's everything else. He's been a Dumper a long time. He just passed off his own peculiar habits on the other man -- it kept things goin'.

Speaker: ross
Dialogue: OK, pretend I believe you. Tell me how you get an indictment.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: Can't. Yet. Oh we got everythin' else: first rate evidence Cable typed those dumper letters to Bree Daniel. And Jane McKenna: Klute found a couple in her personal remains. We got dates of Cable's trips here coincidin' with phone calls to Bree Daniel, also the dates of death of McKenna and Page. We got some hints of his personal history. His father, unsuccessful salesman, committed suicide when he was 13. His mother pinned all her hopes on her son. He won a national science youth award at the age of eight. They had no money, but she hired special tutors for him in the summer time. She saw a good thing. He graduated from high school at 14 -- college at 16 -- no friends -- The kids in his class thought of him as a freak. He got his Ph.D. at 18 -- married at age 21 to his then employer's daughter. The marriage lasted 4 weeks. Her father had it annulled. She says he was impotent. World War II he got in bad trouble about a German girl, no details. We think we know why he killed Grunemann -- he found out Cable was a dumper; Cable couldn't take that. We think we know why he killed McKenna -- she wanted to blackmail him for it. All fine. But we got no body, no direct witnesses, we can't go any-damn-where.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: That's the reason i told him we had no evidence Tom was still alive. We wanted to shake him into another phone call or another letter. It didn't work out just that way.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: Gov, want to leave me that one. How come he got to play with this one, anyway.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I left them here. I was doing some work here.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: It's damn lucky you didn't have the dossier on Cable here.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Nobody's seen that.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: If we get anything from the lab, we'll have it by noon. And just think -- all he really had to do was write us a letter.

Speaker: ross
Dialogue: Sounds to me you better shake him again. Put him in a spot he has to do something more -- but this time give him a time and a place to do it.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: He called this morning from Tuscarora. Asked me to meet him at 3:00 at the downtown heliport. He's on his way to Chicago.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: He sure chalks up a lot of flight time.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Ah, Schmendrick -- what's the scam?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Those were police laboratory people, they've been over the apartment.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Can I go in? I need some stuff.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Where'd you spend last night?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: With Trina.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I called Trina.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Maybe I wasn't there when you called.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Bree, what's actually happened? It wasn't that bad.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: How do you know how bad it was?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Why couldn't you stay here with me?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Because I didn't want to be touched! I didn't think you'd get that!

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Trask wants to talk with you.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Hey -- look officer -- I can explain everything. It was just -- you know, everything all of a --

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Trask wants to talk with you.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: Miss Daniel, be sensible, you find another place till we get things cleaned up.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Oh well that shouldn't take you more than another, oh, two and a half or three years, should it?

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: A few more days. We know who did this.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: So do I.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: No, not Grunemann. He's dead. The man that killed him -- also prob'ly Jane McKenna, also Arlyn Page.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Arlyn and Jane commited suicide. He said they commited suicide.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: Now there's a picture I'd like you to --

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: You said someone killed them, you said you know who, you said that.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: Well we're pretty --

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Why isn't he locked up?

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: We don't want to just lock him up; we want a conviction, we wanted him to do something more.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Is that why Klute didn't tell me?

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: I guess he figured it was better.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: What was better? I made better bait?

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: No, that's not --

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Is that what he set me up for? Everything he's told me from the beginning? -- don't worry, don't --

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: From the beginning I don't know why the hell he's messin with you. If he was me he'd know better. If he was even a city boy he'd know better. You're a whore Miss Daniel, that's the truth of it, right? Now somethin I'd like you to look at.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: I don't have to look at anything. I don't have --

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: Here please.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Oh no.

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: Like for you to look for the man.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Grunemann? I've looked at him a --

Speaker: trask
Dialogue: No. Not Grunemann. The Dumper. Just look around -- I said look for the Dumper.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Oh! --

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: Sorry we had to meet here. But I'm pressed for time.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Well there's a couple --

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: I read your report. I had to go along with it -- the idea of this being a wild goose chase, Tom being nowhere around --

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Well as a matter of --

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: I've been up country, you know my summer place, my camp. I don't even have a telephone there. This morning they sent a messenger out, that you'd been trying to call me.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: I'm on my way to Chicago. Very important meeting tonight. Well -- any new developments?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Yeah, two things Pete, that --

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: You said Trask was arranging laboratory work. Police laboratory. Anything from that?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Yeah. It wasn't Tom.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I don't understand.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: It wasn't Tom that broke in the room.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: It has to be Tom. You said he ripped up his own pictures, he --

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Not Tom. Whoever it was left a kind of souvenir, I told you, in her clothing. Semen. The laboratory got a blood group reading from that. The man was blood type 0; Tom was an AB.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: Some mistake perhaps that --

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: No. No mistake Pete. It doesn't prove who it was -- but proves it wasn't Tom.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: You must be discouraged.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Not too bad. This brings back that Dumper in the picture.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: That who?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Dumper, the man Bree Daniel mentioned and Arlyn Page knew and Jane McKenna knew.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: You said he was no possible connection with Tom. The Page girl told you that, not Tom.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Someone's been doing all these things.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: You were hired to look for Tom, not someone.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Pete, I've got a chance to buy Jane McKenna's black book.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Call-girls generally keep a book, you know, a list of their clients. Sometimes, if a girl retires, she'll even sell it worth good money. Jane McKenna had a black book; when she died it was stolen. I've been after it a long time.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: You were hired to look for Tom.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I'm meeting a man tomorrow night. He wants to meet me on East-River Drive -- he wants five hundred dollars for the book. Can you get that for me Pete?

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: I can't follow you.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Will the Company put up five hundred dollars to get Jane McKenna's list of clients?

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: No. It's ridiculous. This has nothing to do with Tom Grunemann.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I want a look at it anyhow.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: Klute, the Company's interest is Tom Grunemann. Solely and exclusively. You say you can't find Tom; all right, I'll see that you're paid off; the case is closed.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: All right, but I'm going to see that list.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: Why would they deal with you? You don't know these people.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: No, but Bree does. She's negotiating for me. Bree Daniel.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: I can talk it over; possibly I can get the money. When are you meeting the man?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Tomorrow evening, nine. East River Drive and 73rd Street.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: Suppose I meet you there a half hour before.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Just send me a money order.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: No, I'd -- like to be in on it.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Well --

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: Tomorrow. See you tomorrow night.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Bree?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I'm always getting surprises.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Trask said I should move. Let's not make a thing of it.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Look, it's not necessarily how it looks, right? It's --

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: No. Please. Not with this son of a bitch.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Klute, let's handle it like grownups? I mean we're all grown up now, right?  -- we all respect each other, you know what I mean? -- I respect you, Bree respects you -- you could say, it just didn't work out between you and she. But you got to respect her too -- you know, her best interests, best for her --

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Hey, I'm gonna get you dropped.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Please --

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: -- until he gets back.  Yes I heard you, I understand that. I said I'm going to come over, I'll wait until he gets back.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Hello?  Trask, I don't get that.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Who told you, his secretary?  I'll look around, I'll call you back.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Bree --

Speaker: lela
Dialogue: -- I have to close up now. Leave your name and number with his message service, Mrs. Daniel, and why don't you just go home and wait until he --

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: lela
Dialogue: Well I have to close up now.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Look -- could I use your phone?

Speaker: lela
Dialogue: Yes indeed.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Look. I almost killed my -- I almost killed someone.

Speaker: lela
Dialogue: Well I'm certain Doctor Spangler will want to talk with you; excuse me.

Speaker: faber
Dialogue: Yes?  Bree?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: -- I'm -- I just have to talk to someone. I'm just a little way across town --

Speaker: faber
Dialogue: Yes - yes dear, yes -- maybe half an hour, sure, yes.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Trina, will you call me if you hear from, her? Will you check other people she might call? Yeah, if it wasn't trouble I wouldn't ask vou.

Speaker: foreman
Dialogue: Lady, it's closing up there.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: foreman
Dialogue: We're closing up, quitting time, Fabers.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: I have an appointment with Mr. Faber.

Speaker: foreman
Dialogue: Oh, yeah.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: I have an appointment with Mr. Faber.

Speaker: receptionist
Dialogue: In there.  Mr. Faber --

Speaker: nathan
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: I'm sorry -- Mr. Faber Senior.

Speaker: nathan
Dialogue: My father went home about fifteen minutes ago; he wasn't feeling too good.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: It wasn't important.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Did Mr. Faber leave a message for me or anything? Mr. Faber Senior? Bree Daniel.

Speaker: receptionist
Dialogue: Oh, I thought that was for tomorrow.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Bree Daniel. Has he called in yet? Well if he does, I'm at --  Just tell him Bree Daniel; he knows who.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Did she leave a number?  What is the number? --

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: Can't we talk together reasonably, just -- ordinarily?  I know you're expecting some kind of -- extravagant behavior, but believe me -- do you believe me? --

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Yes -- all right --

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: -- We can talk --

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: -- Yes.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: All right, then, an ordinary matter. I'm a quite well off man, I have a -- position to respect. I would feel personally uncomfortable to be connected with a -- certain kind of woman, I'm sure you understand. Do you? Well I'd like to buy Jane McKenna's book.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Yes -- Jane McKenna's book -- I could make a phone call.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: No, you're frightened, you're pretending. Well -- Klute knows about me then. Does everybody know, can you tell me?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: Then it doesn't matter what I do any more, does it?

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: I've got no idea what I shall do.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Will you let me go then?

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: It puzzles me so badly. I've done terrible things but I can't consider myself a terrible man. I've killed three people and I'd still want to say it was accident, do you see?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: If you'll let me go I could tell them what --

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: Tom Grunemann discovered me -- we were here on business together, he discovered me with Jane McKenna. Then I suppose it was the -- the contempt I saw in his face and the certainty that sooner or later he'd use it against me. Within the Company. I endured that as long as I could, do you see?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: I'm sorry, I'm just frightened. Yes.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: Excuse me Miss Daniel?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: I said yes, I see.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: Oh no, I don't think --

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Tell me. I'll listen.  I just want you to tell me.

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: You're willing to listen? You want me just to keep talking?

Speaker: cable
Dialogue: You're a person of no value, you have no value --

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Come on.  Come on.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: I got a call from Ross this morning. Cable owned a plot of woodland -- he'd go there on weekends. They found Tom Grunemann's body buried there. They've notified his wife.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: Oh.  Well it wasn't us city people that did it -- your fine rosy-cheeked country boy.

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Mm.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: You're going back?

Speaker: klute
Dialogue: Mm.

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: bree
Dialogue: You don't believe that either, do you? Why can't you see my side?

Speaker: bree
